items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
1. Classification Changes
	 
a. Position Elimination
Elimination of Executive Director, Government & External Affairs, 100% FTE (9CHAN0209M) in the Chancellor's Office at the District Office effective 01/08/13.
	 
b. Position Establishment
Establishment of Executive Director, Government, & External Affairs, 50% FTE (9CHAN0210M) in the Chancellor's Office at the District Office effective 01/09/13.
	 
2. Employment
	 
a. New Hire
Employment of Police Services Lieutenant (9COPS0202M) in Campus Police at the District Office effective 01/09/13.
	 
3. Change of Status
	 
a. Out of Class Assignment
The employee is working an out of class assignment as Interim Director, Student Life (7CNSS0201M) in Student Life at San Jose City College effective 01/09/13 through 06/30/13.
	 
The employee is working an out of class assignment as Technical Services Supervisor (9ITSS0222S) in ITSS at the District Office effective 01/09/13 through 06/30/13.
	 
b. Change to FTE
The employee will work a reduced FTE of 50%, 12 months per year as Executive Director, Government & External Affairs (9CHAN0210M) in the Chancellor's Office at the District Office effective 01/09/13 through 06/30/14.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District Collective Bargaining Agreement ; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees.  District Policy adopted on April 10, 2007 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval.  All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the bid limit (current bid limit is $81,000) should have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
	 
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts that, although are not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts and purchase orders for the period of November 10, 2012 through December 9, 2012 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details: The Board of Trustees adopted the District's operation budget at its meeting on September 11, 2012.  As required by Board Policy 6250, subsequent budget transfers and revisions must be approved by the Board of Trustees.

The curriculum proposals have been reviewed by the appropriate instructional administrator and by the Instructional Policies and Curriculum Committee (IPCC) acting on behalf of the local Academic Senate. The rigor of the approval process assures that each new recommendation has substance and integrity in relation to its discipline and fills a clear need not being served by existing curriculum.
	 
The courses below have been proposed to address recent Title 5 changes regarding repeatability.
	 
DANCE 009:  Ballet, Fundamentals

ACCEPT AS INFORMATION ITEMS 
Project Highlights 
No Report
	 
Monthly Measure G-2010 Summary Report through December 31, 2012 
Attached please find the Measure G-2010 Summary Report through December, 31, 2012
	 
APPROVE AS ACTION ITEMS 
Contracts
	 
Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) - SALAS O’BRIEN ENGINEERS –PAA #SJCC-03 Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings Design Services
	 
In conjunction with Project #31110 Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings, SALAS O’BRIEN ENGINEERS worked with SJCC and the Program Manager to provide Programming and Assessment services to determine College needs and priorities for extending and modernizing the campus utility infrastructure. They produced a Program Report outlining scopes of work and estimates of probable cost for the projects identified. A PAA to provide Design Services and Construction Phase administration was then negotiated with Salas O’Brien due to their expertise and experience with past projects on campus. 
	 
The Board is asked to approve PAA SJCC-03 to SALAS O’BRIEN ENGINEERS in the amount of $180,000 for Designer/Engineer of Record Services for Project #31110 Utility Extension for New and Existing Buildings.
	 
Contract Revisions and Changes
	 
Change Order No. 001 – RADIANT ELECTRIC, INC. – Evergreen Valley College 21kV Electrical Upgrade Project
	 
On October 9, 2012 the board approved a Contract in the amount of $1,585,000 for upgrades to the primary electrical service at Evergreen Valley College to RADIANT ELECTRIC, INC.  Per the request of the College additional fencing and signage was requested from the Contractor.  This ensures that the campus remains completely secure for the duration of the project and that staff and students onsite have additional wayfinding signals located at high traffic areas.  Change Order No. 001 was negotiated for an additional cost of $14,290 for a revised contract value of $1,599,290.
	 
     Original Contract Amount $1,585,000
     Change Order No. 1           $     14,290
     Revised Contract Amount $1,599,290
	 
The Board is asked to approve issuance of Change Order No. 001 to RADIANT ELECTRIC, INC. in the amount of $14,290 for the Evergreen Valley College 21kV Electrical Upgrade Project.
	 
	 
Bond List Revisions 
a. No Report

items.item_details: Dr. Mike Russell, CampusWorks CISO, will provide a Technology update.
Ms. Rosalie Ledesma, Executive Director Governmental and External Relations, will provide a Legislative update.

The Board has identified that one of the important performance objectives for the Chancellor is to provide a comprehensive review of the District's organization and staffing.  The Chancellor's Initiative - Restructuring/Reorganization 2012-13 will examine and analyze current organizational structures at the unit level using guiding principles which align with future goals.  The goal will be to connect each unit with one other to create an institution that addresses not only the needs of students today but can support advancement and evolution in the years to come.  
	 
The units are defined as San Jose City College, Evergreen Valley College, Workforce Institute and District Offices.
	 
At the January 8, 2013 Board Meeting, the Trustees will be presented with the purpose statement, the guiding principles, the process, the timeline and an outline of the report they will receive in Fall 2013 as information.
	 
At the January 22, 2013 Board Meeting, the Chancellor will make the recommendation to the Trustees to adopt the guiding principles.

Nationwide, the accountability movement has produced a number of definitions for student success including the means to measure student success.  Invariably, these definitions and metrics focus on completion of degrees, certificates, and transfers.  While these are legitimate measures of student success, they do not adequately measure the transformational educational interventions provided by community colleges for community college students.  What is needed is a more comprehensive definition of student success that refocuses the issue of student success as a process and not merely an outcome.
	 
San Jose/Evergreen Community College District trustees and chancellor have in the past few years participated in various efforts for defining student success and establishing policies for student success at national, state, and local levels through the ACCT (Association of Community College Trustees), the CLASS (California Leadership Alliance for Student Success), the State Legislature on SB-1456 and Student Success Task Force Recommendations, and the District’s Board, chief executives, employees and students. 
	 
At the December 13, 2011 Board of Trustee meeting, the Board acted to adopt a resolution for transmittal to the Board of Governors of the CCC urging them to delay their approval of the Student Success Task Force Recommendations to permit more time for system deliberation.  In addition, the Board established a Board Subcommittee on Student Success (Trustee Mayra Cruz, Trustee Maria Fuentes, and Trustee Jeffrey Lease).  The Charge to the Subcommittee was to compare, contrast and analyze these various sources and to present a set of policy constructs that is consonant with the Board’s direction as adopted in its work plan. 
	 
On February 21st, 2012, the Board Subcommittee on Student Success convened an introductory meeting with an expanded constituent group to explore the Committee’s purpose, role and function, guidelines and principles to guide the student success agenda, and definition of terms.   President Fuentes announced that Trustee Cruz will serve as Chair of the Board Subcommittee on Student Success.  The Committee reviewed the CLASS document “Defining a Student Success Agenda.”  The Constituent Group, under the leadership of Chancellor Rita Cepeda, was charged with a number of tasks, including the development and implementation of a legislative advocacy strategy to monitor and address student success related legislation.
	 
The Student Success Constituent Group composed of administrators, faculty, staff, and students (See Attachment A) met on March 27th, April 30th, May 14th, June 21st with the Board Subcommittee, November 1st, and December 20th with the Board Subcommittee to discuss on matters related to Student Success including Student Success definitions, metric, advocacy, and policy.  In addition, representatives of the District’s trustees, staff, and students met over the summer on September 4th, 18th, and 26th to prepare for the presentation on the “District’s Struggle to Own, Define, Quantify, and Actualize a More Responsive and Responsible Definition of Student Success” for the October 3rd Annual Statewide RP (Research and Planning) Conference.  Additional presentations were presented to participants at national, state, and local forums including the ACCT Leadership Congress on October 10th – 13th, the HACU (Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities) Conference on October 21st, the AACC (American Association of Community Colleges) Conference on October 24th – 26th, SJCC Campus Forum on November 6th, and EVC Counseling Department Retreat on December 10th.  
	 
At the December 20th, 2012 Board Subcommittee meeting, the Board Subcommittee members together with our Chancellor, faculty, staff and student representatives thoughtfully reviewed all received input from constituent groups on the draft of the District’s student success definition and policy.  As a result, certain input was incorporated and the Board Subcommittee approved the attached final draft, which is being presented to the full Board for review and adoption.  
The recommendation is for the Board to adopt this final draft of the District’s Student Success Definition and Policy (See Attachment B), at their January 22, 2013 Board meeting.
